headline: Roast Leg of Lamb with Rosemary
description: A leg of lamb is marinated overnight with rosemary, garlic, mustard, honey, and lemon zest, then roasted to perfection for a family-pleasing meal.

video.description: See how to make a simple, sensational lamb roast.
video.name: Roast Leg of Lamb with Rosemary

name: Roast Leg of Lamb with Rosemary

recipeInstructions.text: Mix honey, garlic, rosemary, mustard, lemon zest, and pepper together in a small bowl. Place lamb in a flat dish; rub mixture over lamb. Cover with plastic wrap and marinate in the refrigerator 8 hours to overnight.
Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Transfer lamb onto a rack in a roasting pan and sprinkle with salt to taste.

Bake in the preheated oven for 20 minutes, then reduce heat to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C) and roast for 55 to 60 more minutes for medium rare. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 120 degrees F (50 degrees C). Let lamb rest for about 10 minutes before carving.

review.reviewBody: I used this marinate with lemon juice added on lamb chops overnight. It was very good.

I marinated the leg of lamb for about 7 hours before baking in a cast iron dutch oven with potatoes and carrots along the side. I found the honey was a little too strong and overtook the savory taste of the lamb. We did enjoy the meal and the lamb was very juicy and tender. Next time I think I would reduce or eliminate the honey.
Great recipe for a nice dinner!

I made this recipe per the instructions, but added the balsamic vinegar and olive oil that many reviewers suggested. I had a 3.5 pound leg of lamb, but made the full recipe for the marinade, which is for a 5-pound leg. The meat itself turned out perfectly cooked, but the marinade was way too strong. I think next time I'll leave out the balsamic vinegar and reduce the amount of marinade by about half. Lamb by itself has such great flavor that this marinade covered up. I'll make it again with these modifications.
Easy and delicious!
Turned out just the way I was hoping. Not a lot of experience cooking lamb and none with such a big leg. Will make it again.

This didn't work out too well for me. They honey made it way too sweet. I did add a cup of water in the pan while roasting. I had extra marinade and some of that made it way with the water. Be careful with the honey. Way too sweet.

Absolutely delicious! Didn't change the marinade (that would make it a different recipe) though I did use just a squirt of lemon juice rather than zest. Also had a deboned leg. Cooked for 20 minutes at 450° which created a beautiful crust and added 2 cups of water to the bottom of the roast pan. Reduced the heat to 350° and cooked until meat thermometer read 140° - a perfect medium - for about 1-1/2 hours without foil. I heated the pan drippings on the stove, whisking all the while and made a perfect gravy. I served with roasted garlic buttery whipped potatoes and turnip. Everyone loved the meal and we'll definitely have it again! While it makes a very impressive company meal, we just had it on an ordinary Saturday night. Felt very special. Thanks for this wonderful recipe!
Wonderful recipe.

We raise market lambs and will definitely make this recipe again. I made this for my family and family friends! Everyone raved about the flavor and tenderness. I followed the recipe exactly except I used a lamb shoulder instead of a leg. I waited until the temp was about 165 and it was perfectly pink for everyone’s taste. The drippings and resting juice was to die for when poured over the slices of meat. A wonderful recipe!
Absolutely divine! i bathed the lamb in worchershire sauce, and substituted the lemon zest for McCormick's California style coarse grind blend lemon pepper. Muah!

Thus was a great recipe. I made a wine base sauce with red wine, chicken broth and onions. Mix all ingredients and pour it in the bottom of the pan, before placing the lamb on top of it. It was great for dipping the slice lamb into it.
follow the recipe and it will turn out perfectly
We cooked it and it was tender and delicious! We grilled it.
The cook time was way off! 20 min on 450 degrees then 60 minutes at 400 degrees= crispy outside RAW inside! Cooked for another 45 minutes and it was medium-rare. This through off the rest of dinner!
absolutely delicious!!! first LOL i've cooked.

Temperature was too hot. I covered with foil for the first 20min at 230d, then took it off for the next 60min at 200d. Lamb got burnt outside on top but not medium yet inside. Marinate was a bit too sweet, I added lemon zest and a dash of lemon as suggested by others.

Made this pretty much via the recipe. Technically, this came out perfectly. Flavor wise, I did not appreciate the sweetness. Would have preferred a simpler garlic and rosemary profile. 

 I only had a very strong Buckwheat honey in the house, but picked my rosemary straight out of my pot, and let marinate overnight. I used a convection roast setting on my oven, so dropped each temperature by 25 degrees and cooked it to medium rare on the probe. I did NOT tent it as I like a bit of crust on my meat. Perhaps if I had adjusted with some balsamic as suggested in other comments - but as I have only a long aged (and hence sweet) balsamic on hand in these quarantined times, it would probably still have thrown me off. So easy to follow, technically perfect - but I'll go simpler and savory next time and skip the honey.
I added a squeeze of half a lemon and marinated it for a full 24 hours.

The temperature of 450 for 20 is absurd. I tried that and it quickly cooked smaller parts of the roast. Cooking it at 350 for 1 1/2 to 2 hours. I also found the flavour to be bland. I marinated it for 2 days and the meat was not flavourful. I would not make this again. Lamb, yes, but a different recipe.

This was amazing!! I used balsamic vinaigrette with the ingredients and let it marinade in the fridge for two days. It took a little longer to cook, almost 2 hours until the inside was about 140-150 degrees and it was done perfect! I did add some water at bottom of pan and loosely covered it with tin foil. Could not stop eating it!
Was a hit

The best leg of lamb I have ever had. So tender and tasty. My wife loved it and wants me to make it again. I did add 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar to the marinade and changed the cooking temp to 425 degrees for 20 minutes and then turned the oven down to 350 and cooked it until it reached an internal temp. of 145 degrees. Also added 1 cup water to the pan. Fantastic!
First time I made a leg of lamb.. the whole family liked it!! Had it for Easter dinner.. will make it again ..

I cooked this today for Easter. It was fairly easy, however this roast was cooked too high for the time allotted. I followed the recipe however I took the lamb out at 50 minutes instead of 60 and it was over cooked. The flavor is still okay, however I highly recommend lowering the temperature and possibly the cooking time if you want it medium rare.

This was a big hit at my house!! I followed some other reviewer suggestions and added water. I added a bit of white wine and balsamic vinegar with corn starch to make a gravy. I will be making this again!
Served this on Sunday and it was moist and delicious. Definitely cover it so that the oven stays clean.
My family enjoyed this dish. I added aged balsamic vinegar to the mixture. I finished the dish with a mint marmalade . Fantastic!!!!!!
I forgot the lemon zest, but it turned out ok.

I didn't have time to let it marinade overnight but gave it about 6 hours. Also I let the meat reach room temperature before roasting. Couldn't have been happier with the outcome! Pulled it out as soon as it hit 145' and let it sit. First thought was, it's not going to be done. But once I started slicing, it was done to perfection at a medium to medium rare! Can't wait to try it again and let it marinade overnight.
Everyone loves this!

Superb flavor! I added 1 tbsp balsamic vinegar. I also covered the pan with foil until the last 10 minutes and added 3 cups of water. I recommend putting foil on the base of the pan so it's not a mess to clean.
I didn't have honey so I used real maple syrup. It tasted pretty good but the marinade burned. Smelled bad for hours Next time I won't do the marinade
I made this for my family on Christmas - it was DELISH! I marinated it in a plastic bag in the morning & we had it for dinner...perfect! It's on the menu for 2019!
It wasn’t bad, but I didn’t feel like it added any magic to warrant the marinating time. Will go back to regular roasting with garlic and rosemary I think.
This lamb was by far the best recipe I have ever tried for lamb!

I marinated the roast overnight and the flavor was wonderful. I should have paid closer attention to the comments though, as the roast charred on the outside and was not done enough in the center using the temps as given. I would definitely use this recipe again.

This was my first attempt at making lamb of ANY kind. I was impressed with how straightforward it was. The video really helped, because it suggested adding lemon juice (recommended by one reader), which I did, and also putting foil over it if it was starting to burn. My husband enjoyed it as much as I did.
Came out great. I did not use foil but i did put water in the bottom of the roasting pan with lamb on rack above to keep moist.

I made exactly as written but only marinated a couple of hours. The result was very good flavor and tenderness. My big regret was that I did not think to line my pan with foil as the balsamic and honey combo made a very big stuck on mess! I think I will eventually get it all off but warning to other cooks.

This was amazing! It’s an easy to follow recipe for a meal that cost you a pretty penny. My husband kids and mother in law loved it! I did add the lemon juice to the marinade as suggested by many reviewers and the meat was very tender. If you’re thinking about making this dish, think no more and just make it! I would suggest you line the bottom of the pan with foil as per the instructions. I failed to do this and it took a couple days of soaking and light scrubbing to get it off my cast iron baking pan.
Seasoning was great.just think my cut of meat was very fatty and took away from it. May try with another cut
My wife made this it turned out delicious even only marinating a 6 hours.
Followed the recipe almost to the tee.....boneless leg.....very good, made great gravy!!!
This was great! Roast came out perfectly! Marinade was easy and made a nice crust on the roast. Will do this one again.
I followed this recipe except for the garlic (one of my guests is allergic to garlic) and I felt it wasn’t quite right so…either I follow the recipe or not at all. My fault entirely!
The recipe turned out well but I didn't care for the taste of lamb.
The recipe is perfect. I just increased Dijon mustard, garlic, pepper, salt and rosemary quantity. I also kept it at 200 C for 1 hr 35 min for perfect pink medium rare.

I am new at this online recipe thing. I wish I had read the "most helpful" comments before hand: it would have saved my roasting pan from being destroyed by burned drippings. Next time I will 1) use lemon juice instead of zest and add Balsamic Vinegar and olive oil to the marinade, 2) reduce the heat to 400/325, 3) tent it except for last 15 min, 4) put water in the bottom of the pan (I do this for turkey, but didn't think of it in this case). My guests really loved it and I think these steps would make it perfect!
I substituted orange peel for lemon zest.

Bet leg of lamb ever. The 24 hour marinade did the trick. Super tender and I could taste it all; the rosemary, the Dijon, the garlic (and the ground fresh mint I added) that the long marinade infused subtly into the meat. It came out a gorgeous reddish tint with a fine crust/patina (ramped up the heat o 45 for the last 15 minutes). I WILL make this again and again.. totally worth adding some mint to the marinade and doubling the garlic.
Very easy to make. A nice balance of flavors. I would definitely make this again.
The whole family loved it! A keeper!
Undo the lamb from the netting before cooking!!

I changed the marinade a bit, we made this for a jewish holiday where they add honey for a sweet new year. So I added 1/4 cup of honey and a quarter cup of whiskey. I used the balsamic vinegar fresh chopped rosemary.

The honey and whiskey added a great flavour and removed a bit of the gaminess of the lamb. It also made an amazing gravy.
We didn't make any changes to this recipe except for putting it on the grill instead of using the oven. The lamb was delicious. We'll use this recipe again.
Very nice. Don't over cook the meat!
We substituted lemon juice for the zest (we didn't have a lemon) and added balsamic vinegar to the marinade. It was a crowd pleaser and we got requests for the recipe.
Wonderful. My daughter kept asking for more.

Very tasty, we don't have lamb very often so was unsure how this would turn out, could not be more satisfied with the result. Reading the reviews I did add some balsamic vinegar and marinated in a gallon ziplock bag overnight turning and massaging it a few times. the leftovers made an amazing lamb curry a couple of days later.
Took longer to cook than recipe stated. Cooked exactly as directed. Flavor was great, meat was moist ans tender.

Very tasty! I didn't have fresh rosemary, so I used dried, and I blended the ingredients before adding the meat. And then I marinated it for 2 days. Those were my only changes. My family really liked it, especially with the leftover marinade simmered down into a thick gravy.
Will definitely make again!

I followed the suggestions to add olive oil, balsamic and lemon juice. I added a tad bit extra dijion to the marinade. I marinated it over night in a turkey bag. I cooked it at 300 degrees for 2 1/2 hours because I had to leave for church. It was medium well but so juicy and tender. I used the drippings and thickened it with cornstarch and used it as a sauce to top it. It was so wonderful. Everyone ate it even Rhodes who don't like lamb. I'm already having requests to make it again. This is going into my recipe box!

I followed the recipe exactly, & will NOT be making it again. It was really bland, too sweet & the mustard flavor just did not go well with the lamb. I'm going back to my trusty balsamic vinegar and rosemary recipe.

I'm a over committed mom of 3 and I forgot to marinade overnight. Instead it marinade d only 3 hours. I also decided to leave the marinade on while in the oven. I set it to cook while we were at church so I set the timer for 1 1/2 hours at 350. It was perfect!! This is now MY annual Easter lamb
Made it without the pecans, and it still was wonderful. Will be my go-to recipe. Love it!
Joe/Laurel were here for Passover and they all loved the lamb. Did not have time to marinade it for overnight, but only a couple of hrs. Had added the water. Had used the granular Dijon.

I am on a low-salt diet and this recipe was packed with flavor, even though I left out salt and pepper, and used lemon juice instead of zest. The drippings were a great addition to the pan-fried carrots, celery, onions and potatoes served as accompaniment.

I made this following the directions, as well as the suggestions made by Sue Webb-Smith. This was my very first leg of lamb, and I admit I was nervous. It turned out to be spectacular! Everyone, even the one guest who wasn't sure he would like lamb, never having tried it, went. Ack for seconds. Thank you JMASS and Sue!
Nice recipe, served it at Thanksgiving and it was a big hit

I found this one of the best leg of lamb recipes that I have prepared. It is a big more complicated than the non-marinade versions, but it produces a very nice result.

My only major variations were that I added the juice of the lemon along with the lemon zest. I simply did not want to waste the lemon, and it seemed to work out well. I also used the minced garlic in a jar primarily because I already had that handy. My Dijon style mustard was Gray Poupon. And due to my work schedule, I started the marinade process the evening before, meaning that the leg of lamb essentially was marinaded 24 hours.

My leg of lamb was roughly 7 lbs, and the recommended cooking time was underestimated quite a bit. Instead of 50-60 minutes, it took me about 90 minutes or 1 bottle of malbec. Use a meat thermometer so that you can plan to have your sides ready when needed.

I would recommend this recipe, and I would make it again. I would give it 4.5 stars if possible, primarily because of the cooking time estimate being a bit off, at least in my case.

I put the roast in the roasting pan and poured remaining marinade over and around it. By the time it had cooked at 450 for 20 minutes the marinade was completely evaporated/dry and starting to smoke. Thankfully I was able to pour about 2 cups of water in the roasting pan to slow the process and the meat didn't not pick up the scorched taste but the "gravy" was certainly scorched beyond using. Flavor of the meat was good but since I used a boneless leg of lamb it was very tough. Won't use boneless leg of lamb ever again because this has happened before.

I followed the recipe amounts, but changed it as suggested on Susan's comment, added the balsamic vinegar and water and followed exactly the baking times, except baked 10 min less at 350. Turned out fantastic. This was my first time cooking lamb. Thank you.
Absolutely worth it. Poke wholes while you marinade it to get more flavor inside.

Good recipe for Lamb and even use it on Lamb shoulder steak and put the on the grill. This recipe helps with that lamb gamy taste that some people don't enjoy. Always a hit at my family Easter party and have to be sure to go with medium rare on it.
Added lemon juice
Easy to make and absolutely delicious.
This was very flavorful. Loved it!
I added carrots and red potatoes. Made a gravy from the drippings. Yum!

This was an easy recipe, and overall tasty. We had no complaints for our Thanksgiving dinner and it was beautiful! I added fresh sage and other herbs, which enhanced the flavor. If i do it again, I'd like to make more marinade, since you could only taste it if you hade the end slices. I'd put some extra salt in and probably try to use a mixture of marinade and broth to make the gravy. Overall, very happy.
This is the best leg of lamb recipe I've ever made. Guests love it.
Made it just like the recipe states, absolutely delicious!
We loved this. The honey made a crisp edge. All the flavors melded beautifully

Very nice marinade. Had a 3-pound butterflied leg of lamb. Rolled it after marinating. Roasted @ 425 for 20 minutes, then ai 350 for about an hour until meat thermometer read 130. Let rest 15 minutes. Followed the marinade recipe, then added a bit of lemon juice. Husband loved it! Served with roasted summer squash from this site. Delicious!

I made the marinade exactly as written but changed cooking technique based on another recipe. I put the oven on broil and seared my boneless leg on one side for 7 mins or so, then did same on other side. I then reduced heat to 325 and roasted to an internal temp of 135, then let rest for 15 mins. This resulted in a medium doneness. I did add water based on other reviews, 1 cup initially, and added as the water reduced. While the roast was resting, I made a sauce by adding red wine and thickening with a flour and water slurry. This was my first try with a lamb roast (I usually do chops), and I would definitely make this again. It was delicious!

I made this using the marinade as a sauce to cook it in the slow cooker. The only change I made was to add 2/3 cup of cooking sherry as a liquid to the marinade and I also made slices in the leg of lamb and inserted garlic cloves.. The Leg of lamb was boneless. Yummy.

This recipe turned out delicious. I often struggle with getting lamb just right, but this tasted so yummy, I was sneaking pieces out of the pan long after I was full! I'll be keeping this recipe!

I started with a boneless leg of lamb and trimmed all the fat off, which resulted in smaller pieces. These I marinated for about 36 hours and then baked at 375 for 25 minutes. Yum! The only drawback was the rosemary, which gave a good flavor but was like hard little pellets to chew. Next time I'll crush the rosemary or something beforehand.

I took a boneless leg of lamb and trimmed the fat off, resulting in smaller pieces, which I marinated for about 36 hours. Then I baked it for about 25 minutes at 375. It turned out delicious! My new favorite for lamb, which is a meat I often have trouble getting just right.
This was really very good. Guests enjoyed it and it was not hard to make. Win: Win.

All our offspring couldn't stop talking about how well it tasted.

Will certainly use again.
yummy yummy
Great for Easter Sunday dinner. I'll be making it again.

OMG the first time making lamb and this recipe did not disappoint at all. So tasty and juicy, I did listen to a few other reviewers and added the lemon juice and splash of balsamic to the marinade. This lamb leg is out of this world

Made this tonight and had rave reviews for Easter dinner. Used the suggestions provided by Sue-Webb-Smith. I had to add more water to the bottom of the pan midway through. In the end I just recreated the marinade and added lime juice, red wine and butter to make a very tasty sauce. This recipe is definitely a keeper!
First attemp at cooking lamb, very impressed. I made a marinade with walnut oil, Rosemary, garlic, and lemon. The meat was supper tender, juicy, will definitely try again.

It's hard for me to tell you a lot about this recipe. I don't like lamb and rarely eat more than a bite or two covered in horseradish sauce. 
I 've made it about 3 times for our church and they love it. Attendance at this event has doubled since I've used it. 
Watch the temperature - I use boneless roasts. Pull out and let it rest. Check the temperature carefully, don't use beef temperatures. 
We trim the meat well. Marinate over night and roast. Happy Easter.

Great flavour but the only thing was it needed to be cooked maybe 1/2 hr more. I used the exact marinade recipe and placed all in a bag to sit for 2hours. While cooking I did cover the roast with foil to prevent over browning and added water to the bottom of the pan. Quite enjoyable.

The marinade for this is awesome! I have made it twice and each time the lamb turned out super tasty. I cooked it differently though, browned the lamb leg on all sides and the cooked it at 375F in the oven for 1 hour for 5 pounds and 1 hour and 20 mins for a 7 pound leg. Then with the drippings made a red wine based sauce with some thyme, rosemary, a bit of oil and green onions. Delicious!

item.name: Roast Leg of Lamb with Rosemary
